Description: Solid-cast mirror in copper alloy; circular shape with a simple projecting tang to which was attached a missing handle; flat, plain surface; corroded.
Curator's comments: Object owned and held by the Museum of Fine Arts, Boston. This record is included in the British Museum database as part of the Museum’s Naukratis Project, a research collaboration that aims to virtually re-unite finds from the ancient port city of Naukratis, now distributed over 80 museums worldwide.

Mirrors had more than a pure domestic function. According to iconographic and archaeological evidences, they could be an object of cult, either offered as an ex-voto or part of the funerary equipment (Robinson 2010, 219-220). Robinson, Z. 2010, ‘Living with Metals in Hellenistic Egypt – New Finds from Heraclion-Thonis’, in D. Robinson and A. Wilson (eds.), Alexandria and the North-West Delta, Oxford, 219–231.
